attachments.fallback:
[May 25th, 2019 4:00 AM] stefanlesser: A few people here have been posting about category theory. I’ve been learning category theory for the last few weeks trying a few different approaches and found resources that work well for me. If you’re interested here's my current “curriculum”: <https://gist.github.com/stefanlesser/7f0749b3a38078b3eebe0cc408345e9f>

Is anybody here interested in forming a (virtual?) study group? I noticed how much more effective it is to talk to people about it. Would be great to find people who are actually interested in me explaining it to them. ;-) Obviously, I’d also be very interested in having others explain it to me as well.

Pretty open about the structure. Could be sort of a book club working through the resources, weekly video calls to discuss and explain to each other, share exercise results, or even do “pair programming” on the exercises. Whatever you feel comfortable with and are interested in. However, you should be genuinely interested in putting some effort into it, which maybe means you can commit to read a few chapters a week and then meet online to discuss them.

My goal is to build intuitive understanding for category theory concepts and its applications. I’m less interested in learning all the proofs and more in what it means that for instance natural transformations map to parametric polymorphism and what we can use these kinds of insights for to create better programming languages and environments. I’ve made it far enough to totally believe in but not yet far enough to know how to take advantage of the Eric Weinstein quote:
>“Theoretical mathematicians are sitting on top of a giant stockpile of intellectual gold. They have so many things that have not been manifested anywhere. You have no idea how much great stuff that these priests have in their monastery.”
which is on the Conexus website that <@UJK8MKYAZ> linked to above. 

Reply here or DM me.

text:
We had a great first meeting and here's our plan moving forward:
• We plan to meet weekly (find the next date down below)
• We agreed that until next time we will read or watch Bartosz Milewski's _Category Theory for Programmers_ preface + chapter 1 or videos 1.1 + 1.2
• We used Zoom this time and will try it again next time

text: Just got through the first lecture. I was really digging it, until he popped his own balloon and reduced Category Theory to a branch of neuroscience.

elements.text: Just got through the first lecture. I was really digging it, until he popped his own balloon and reduced Category Theory to a branch of neuroscience.

text: I’d love ya’lls reaction to this. Epistemology is something highly interested in and passionate about, and it seemed a self-contradiction to say that category theory both doesn’t correspond to the real world and is helps us study it.

elements.text: I’d love ya’lls reaction to this. Epistemology is something highly interested in and passionate about, and it seemed a self-contradiction to say that category theory both doesn’t correspond to the real world and is helps us study it.

text: Moreover, scientists are always telling us nature has no teleology - if that’s true, he seems to rather put the cart before the horse in saying that the teleology of minds (make babies, I guess?) precludes us from having true knowledge of the world, and that all the deep relationships mathematicians and philosophers are finding in diverse fields are merely an artifact of the kinds of thoughts our brains can have.

elements.text: Moreover, scientists are always telling us nature has no teleology - if that’s true, he seems to rather put the cart before the horse in saying that the teleology of minds (make babies, I guess?) precludes us from having true knowledge of the world, and that all the deep relationships mathematicians and philosophers are finding in diverse fields are merely an artifact of the kinds of thoughts our brains can have.

text: <@UFBQNBYER> has joined the channel

A quote from GK Cherston may explain (indirectly) why I’m grumpy about this:
>  A flippant person has asked why we say, “As mad as a hatter.” A more flippant person might answer that a hatter is mad because he has to measure the human head.

elements.text: A quote from GK Cherston may explain (indirectly) why I’m grumpy about this:
A flippant person has asked why we say, “As mad as a hatter.” A more flippant person might answer that a hatter is mad because he has to measure the human head.

yeah, I think overemphasis on 'science' generally irritates me—it's not the only way we have available to think rigorously! and a lot of social psychology and neuroscience could use an re-introduction to, for example, the naturalistic fallacy

elements.text: yeah, I think overemphasis on 'science' generally irritates me—it's not the only way we have available to think rigorously! and a lot of social psychology and neuroscience could use an re-introduction to, for example, the naturalistic fallacy

text: or just philosophy in general

text: <@UJN1TAYEQ> has joined the channel

<@UJK8MKYAZ> I usually cut people slack when they dive off the deep end.  Non-philosophers tend to be a little bit loose with notions, so more nice to choose the favorable interpretation of what people say.  (The alternative is what you get at a Philosophy conference where most people will literally read an abridged version of their paper so as to avoid saying anything embarrassing.)  I will agree though that reduction to neuroscience is irritating.  I mean really?  Is there something about this that is specific to speech or vision or social relationships?  Lots of things are – don't get wrong – but categories?  Objects and arrows with composition: there isn't much there there to be specific to humans.
